In connection with the recent reset of power in Ukraine, it was heard that the decentralization reform, which had begun in 2014, could be suspended and even reversed. By October 2019, it became apparent that the worst fears were not realized: after a pause that arose in connection with the election calendar, decentralization reform continues. This is evidenced by both public discourse and a number of decisions made by the new leadership of the country, including the program of the new government. At the same time, the conflict situation around local self-government in the capital of Ukraine - Kiev - forces one to be on the alert and with increased attention to fears of a different kind - fears that the unnecessarily hasty steps of the new government to complete the reform may carry a number of dangers. One of the Ukrainian experts, who is rightly called the author of the decentralization reform, Anatoly Tkachuk, in a recent interview with the authoritative Kiev weekly journal “Mirror of the Week” points to the risk of an incorrect sequence of stages of reform implementation. This article aims to clarify the path that decentralization reform has already passed under the previous government (2014-2019), to identify its key achievements and challenges, both the final result and the contribution of the reform to the territorial consolidation of Ukraine depend on their successful overcoming.



1. A genuine transfer of power has begun
Democratization often leads to decentralization, since the emergence of political pluralism generates social demands for the redistribution of power between the central and subnational levels of government in favor of the latter. Before Euromaidan of 2013-14, or the Revolution of Dignity, state power in Ukraine was concentrated in Kiev, which controlled resources and powers throughout the country. However, the administrative capacity to provide local administrative and social services was often insufficient. The country combined centralism and weak local government with serious territorial fragmentation.
Ukraine suffered and still partially suffers from significant interregional imbalances regarding the level and quality of economic development and public administration in different areas. One could observe some particular achievements within the framework of the old system before Euromaidan, such as the more or less adequate functioning of the self-government of a number of large cities and partially successful financial decentralization. However, the huge imbalance between the power of the center and the power of municipalities remained an obstacle to the creation of a steadily functioning post-Soviet state.
Only after Euromaidan did a genuine transfer of power begin from the central to the subnational - above all municipal - level. In 2014-15, Ukrainian reformers began a series of parallel and profound changes aimed at improving multi-level governance, promoting subnational democracy and promoting local economic development. Their ambitious and comprehensive plan for decentralization of power is aimed at expanding the capabilities of local (and less regional or district) self-government, as well as changing the administrative-territorial map of the country in order to increase the level of providing educational, medical, social, administrative and other educational institutions to various state bodies and self-government institutions. services.
Ukrainian decentralization is partially based on foreign examples - especially on somewhat similar reforms in Poland in the 1990s - and is backed up by Western technical support. However, this process is largely a “domestic product” of Ukraine, i.e. generated by national, not external impulses, reform. It is based mainly on lessons learned from Kiev’s previous - often unsuccessful - attempts to improve governance at the subnational level until 2014.
This article outlines some key achievements and obstacles to Ukrainian decentralization since 2014. At the end of the text, the presence of a time-limited “window of opportunity” for the operational completion of the first stage of the reform is indicated. Also identified are some of the challenges associated with the second phase of decentralization, which began in January 2019 (see Section 5).
The main problem for decentralization in Ukraine over the past five years has been the gap between the ambitious intentions of the reformers and the limited institutional capacity available to make and implement political decisions in the originally proposed timeframes of 2014-17. After Euromaidan, the new political leadership in Kiev demonstrated their political will and desire to embark on real reforms, despite the enormous external threats to security and the related internal challenges to Ukraine’s territorial integrity. However, the continued resistance from some parts of the elite, especially in the parliament (7th and 8th convocations), prevented, for example, the attempt to include new decentralization installations in the Constitution and thereby create a completely updated administrative structure of local and regional governments of the regional and district levels , as well as territorial structure. Although the reform has already led to significant changes at the local level, it thus has not yet achieved its goal of fundamentally restarting the modus operandi of the Ukrainian state based on the full disclosure of the potential of local self-government and a more effective multi-level government.
The main achievement of decentralization so far is the beginning of the territorial consolidation of municipalities and the concomitant expansion of the rights and opportunities of local self-government of these enlarged communities (communities). At the end of 2014 and the beginning of 2015, budgetary decentralization and the unification of old, often small local communities into larger, independent and self-sufficient so-called societies simultaneously began. "United territorial communities" (OTG). These completely new subjects of the political system of Ukraine received both significant powers to collect taxes and direct transfers from the central state budget. Following the example of the Baltic countries and Scandinavia, OTG, for example, receive 60% of the collected income tax from individuals.
This in-depth process created the prerequisites for the emergence of a new social contract between citizens, authorities and local entrepreneurs. Decentralization, for example, encourages local councils to maintain and expand their tax base, i.e. to attract business and investment. OTGs also take on additional responsibility for providing public services and promoting infrastructure.
An important feature of Ukrainian decentralization today is that the formation of OTG is carried out on a voluntary basis, which contributes to the development of local democracy. Although initially the old communities themselves decide - at least for now - to unite or not to unite in the OTG, as soon as they begin the unification process, they follow the procedures established by the central government. The regional state administration prepares and the regional council approves a “long-term plan” for the formation of OTG in its region. Then this long-term plan is approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. Proposed OTGs must meet certain criteria in order to be recognized by the government as “efficient” (ie, self-sufficient and capable of self-government). After this, the community unites, as a result of the elections appointed by the Central Election Commission, new self-government bodies are elected, and after this the OTGs receive additional funds and powers.
Thanks to the democratic approach to planning and creating OTG, since 2015, many Ukrainians have gained valuable experience in organizing effective collective actions within the legal framework. They become participants in discussions of local government issues and take responsibility for joint decision-making. After the creation of new OTG, elections are held in new local governments with expanded powers, responsible for the development of infrastructure and the distribution of public funds, as well as for the performance of many regulatory functions previously performed by the regional and district administrations and councils.
Over the past five years, the rapid union of communities has radically changed Ukraine. By September 2019, 951 new OTGs were created across the country, where approximately one third (29.1%) of the population of Ukraine live. Since May 2018, densely populated “cities of regional significance”, which already had relatively broad rights, were also connected to the voluntary association. New OTGs differ in their population: the number of residents ranges from 1,000 to 373,000, and averages just over 10,000. Some OTGs cover territories so large that they duplicate the boundaries of the districts. Thanks to its expanded tax collection authority and direct budgetary relations with the center, the OTG is now in a position to take responsibility for the provision of a number of public services that were previously centrally managed by district state administrations.
The second stage of decentralization, announced in January 2019, provides for a radical reduction in the number of districts by combining and creating new administrative and territorial units at this subregional level. Kiev also plans to grant the right to regional and district councils (i.e., already existing self-government bodies) to create their own executive committees and for this purpose intends to formally establish such a new order in the Constitution. However, in the first half of 2019, progress towardsand these goals were insignificant, as political and state figures were busy holding regular presidential and extraordinary parliamentary elections.
Nevertheless, the prospects for continuing the reform of local self-government look generally rosy. It is unlikely that this far-reaching deep transformation of the post-Soviet Ukrainian government can be halted or reversed. Continuity in this process today seems to be the most likely scenario for the next four to five years.



2. Why and how do local communities unite
Ukraine is a unitary state with three levels of administrative-territorial division. At the regional level there are 24 regions, the Autonomous Republic of Crimea and two cities with special status - Kiev and Sevastopol. These regions are divided into 490 districts. Before the decentralization reform started at the local level, there were about 10,900 municipalities, i.e. communities of cities, towns, villages, etc.
Voters in Ukraine directly elect regional, district, and local councils. However, at present, regional and district councils do not have the constitutional right to create their own executive committees. They delegate the implementation of their decisions to regional and district state administrations, whose heads are appointed by the President. This institutional structure significantly limits the self-government of regions and districts. On the contrary, municipalities have the constitutional right to create their own executive bodies. However, with the exception of large cities, until recently, the basic units of self-government of Ukraine were often too small and poor to ensure the provision of public services to residents at an appropriate level and thus were dependent on the help of higher authorities under the control of the center.
After Euromaidan, the government initially sought to carry out a simultaneous reform of self-government, both at the regional, district and local levels. In addition to facilitating the unification of territorial communities and providing the new OTG with additional powers to collect taxes and make decisions, the idea was to simultaneously allow regional and district councils to create their own executive committees. However, until now, parliament has been able to approve legislation only on municipal self-government, territorial consolidation, and voluntary merging of communities in OTG. The expansion of self-government at the regional and district level, as originally envisaged by the reformers, has not yet occurred.
In April 2014, the Cabinet of Ministers adopted the "Concept of reforming local self-government and the territorial organization of state power of Ukraine." This fundamental document introduced the agenda for decentralization reform, which included the expansion of local government, increasing the state’s capacity in the provision of public services and a radical change in the administrative structure and territorial division of the country.
An unprecedented amount of international technical and financial assistance has contributed and continues to contribute to the implementation of Ukrainian decentralization. The multilateral donor initiative “U-LEAD with Europe” plays perhaps a key role in supporting this reform, with its “House of Decentralization” in Kiev, regional offices in 24 regions and extensive, mainly provided by the EU financial resources (about 100 million euros )
Countries that particularly support decentralization of Ukraine include Germany, Sweden, Canada, Poland, and Switzerland. The United States launched two of its own multi-million dollar projects in support of decentralization under the abbreviations “PULSE” (Policies for Local Government of Ukraine) and “DOBRE” (Decentralization that Provides Better Results and Efficiency). The Restoration and Peacebuilding Program in Ukraine, implemented by the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), also focuses on decentralization. In total, Western donors today have allocated more than 250 million euros for Ukrainian decentralization and related reforms.
Since 2017, Ukraine has received additional assistance in the form of specialized advice on decentralization from Germany, which is provided through the G7 envoy, Professor Georg Milbradt, former Minister of President of Saxony. Ukraine also enjoys legal expertise on decentralization bills provided by various Council of Europe programs, including through the project “Decentralization and Local Government Reform in Ukraine”.
Unlike the experience of previous reforms, the current decentralization process benefits from extremely close coordination between international partners. There is close cooperation between foreign partners and the Ministry of Regional Development, Construction and Housing and Communal Services (since September 2019 - the Ministry of Development of Communities and Territories) of Ukraine - the state body responsible for the reform. The cooperation was institutionalized through the Council of Donors on the Decentralization Reform in Ukraine, which includes thematic working groups and evaluates the results. Until 2019, the co-chairs of the Donor Council were (now former) Deputy Prime Minister Gennady Zubko (at the same time holding the post of Minister of Regional Development, Construction and Housing and Communal Services), as well as a representative of international donors.
Some of the most important early decentralization initiatives concerned territorial reorganization and redistribution of the country's finances. Since 2015, the parliament has adopted several laws regulating the voluntary merger of communities in OTG. The new consolidated OTGs are now almost entirely responsible for local development and the provision of basic public services. According to the mentioned Concept of the reform of local self-government and territorial organization of state power of Ukraine, about 10 900 (mostly very small) local communities of the country should have been combined into about 1200 OTG. However, at the end of 2018, then Prime Minister Vladimir Groysman already mentioned another final amount of OTG - from 1,600 to 1,800 such units.
Using the currently existing voluntary procedure, residents of neighboring communities themselves begin and direct the process of unification. The central government provides official recommendations on the creation of self-sufficient OTG capable of providing basic services in the fields of health care, school education, etc. At the same time, the central and regional bureaucracy is involved. Regional administrations are developing “long-term plans” for the formation of united communities for each region in accordance with the criteria established by the central government. Regional councils approve plans, which, in turn, must also be approved by the central government.
Local governments initiating voluntary associations may consult on their long-term plans for the formation of OTG, but are not required to do so. After they have prepared draft decisions of local councils on unification with each other, they officially inform the relevant regional state administration of their intentions. This is done in order to obtain their consent and confirmation that the corresponding draft decision does not violate the Constitution and laws of Ukraine. As soon as consent is received, local initiators complete the community merger, and the corresponding regional state administration asks the Central Election Commission to announce the first elections in the newly created OTG.
Thus, the first local elections to the OTG council mark the final stage of voluntary community unification into a new enlarged community. By September 2019, 848 OTGs had held their first elections, neighboring territorial communities had joined 35 “cities of regional significance”, and another 69 OTGs are now waiting for a decision of the Central Election Commission, allowing them to hold their first local elections, which are likely to take place before the end of 2019 of the year.
If in 2015-2019, community unification in OTG was initiated voluntarily by local councils, then in 2020 the government intends to move to administrative incentives for unification of those territorial communities that have not yet been included in the (previously voluntary) procedure for forming OTG. This is necessary to accelerate the process of creating OTG nationwide before the next nationwide local elections scheduled for October 2020.
Budget decentralization began at the end of 2014, when parliament amended the Budget and Tax Codes. These changes provided the new OTG with budgetary benefits similar to those that had already been provided to the "cities of regional significance", which were previously the only municipalities with full self-government. At present, OTGs are entitled to direct intergovernmental relations with the central government and to a significant portion of local tax revenues (including 60% of personal income tax).
In addition, OTG receive subsidies from the central government, including until 2020 inclusively - funds for the creation of its new institutional and social infrastructure. Special subsidies are also allocated between communities for eliminating imbalances in local development. The financial capacities of OTG are also strengthened by subventions for health (until July 2018) and education. This allows them to take greater responsibility for the provision of public services. For example, OTGs are responsible for managing primary and secondary education in their territories. This contrasts with the situation in communities that have not yet united: self-government remains weak there, the local bureaucracy still depends on the heads of state administrations at the regional and district levels.
The formation of OTG in Ukraine was relatively quick compared to similar refoRami in other European states. The first 159 OTGs were created in 2015, the next year their number grew to 366, by the end of 2017 - to 665, and by the end of 2018 - to 874. As of July 2019, there were already 924 OTGs (see Figure 1 )



The unification process involves both rural and urban municipalities. On average, each OTG unites 4.6 small communities and totals 10,758 residents. However, the distribution of OTG by region is uneven: some areas are already largely covered by OTG, while in others the unification has barely begun. It is noteworthy that there are supporters of voluntary association throughout the country, and their distribution does not follow any linguistic or other cultural patterns. Zhytomyr and Chernihiv regions in the north, Zaporizhzhya and Dnepropetrovsk regions in the east and Khmelnitsky region in the west took the leading positions in the process of forming OTG.
Budget decentralization
Following amendments to the Budget and Tax Codes at the end of 2014, fiscal decentralization quickly advanced. The share of local budgets in the state budget increased from 42% in 2014 to almost 50% in 2018, i.e. similar to the level in many EU member states. If in 2014 the total amount of revenues to local budgets amounted to 68.6 billion UAH. (then about 4.2 billion US dollars), then by 2018 this figure has grown to more than 200 billion UAH. (then about 7.2 billion US dollars) - the growth, which even taking into account the simultaneous devaluation and inflation of the hryvnia, was impressive. The share of local taxes and fees in the revenues of municipal budgets increased from 0.7% in 2014 to 26.1% in 2018.
New OTGs are increasingly dependent on local revenues and to a lesser extent on the financial resources provided by the center. The growth of OTG revenues is accompanied by an increase in the share of expenses for the provision of public services in OTG, which, in turn, aggravates the budgets of OTG. At the same time, the central government continues to provide direct financial support to OTG and invest in local and regional development projects, which OTG can apply for co-financing.
In December 2018, the National Institute for Strategic Studies, the state analytical center in Kiev, summed up the interim results: “Almost 15 percent of Ukraine’s GDP is redistributed through local budgets. In 2018, the share of local budget revenues amounted to (in total) 7.1% of GDP (5.1% in 2014), local budget revenues increased from UAH 68.6 billion. in 2015 to 189.4 billion UAH. [in 2018]. The share of local budgets (including transfers from the center) in the total budget of Ukraine increased from 45.6% in 2015 to 51.5% in 2018. [...] The amount of financing for the development of territories from the state budget increased from 0.5 billion UAH. in 2014, up to 19.3 billion UAH. in 2018. Compared to 2014, state support for the development of territorial communities and improvement of their infrastructure has grown 39 times. The amount of state subsidies for the formation of administrative structures of OTG amounted to UAH 1.9 billion in 2018, and for 2019 the amount of such subsidies is planned at UAH 2.1 billion. ”In 2019, 79 state support programs for territorial development are being implemented in Ukraine, for which more than 84 billion UAH is provided, while in 2018 the volume of such support amounted to more than 66 billion UAH.
Opinion polls show an improvement in public attitudes towards reforms, in particular towards decentralization, including budgetary. A comparative analysis of the thematic sociological surveys that were presented at the Council of Europe Office in Ukraine on March 4, 2019 is indicative. During the 2015 survey, 19% of respondents said that decentralization led to positive changes in their localities. In 2018, this share increased to 39.5%; in the same year, 22% of respondents said they had heard of positive changes in other localities and expect similar improvements where they live. According to the same survey in 2018, 49% of residents of Ukraine said they consider decentralization a reform that promotes regional and local development - community development.
Local democracy
Voluntary unification of territorial communities contributed to the development of local democracy. The initiation, preparation, and process of self-merging communities increased grassroots political and civic engagement. The subsequent creation of local authorities of the OTG with expanded powers has equally favorable consequences.
The OTG self-government bodies include: (a) the head of the OTG, who is elected in direct elections; (b) a local council elected in direct elections with its own executive committee; (c) elders who are representatives of residents of villages and towns outside the OTG administrative center (as of September 2019, there are already 3,207 elders in OTG in Ukraine). Thus, the institutional structure of OTG is aimed at ensuring the representation of residents of each of those (often small and weak) communities that are united in OTG.
The more competent and financially secure local governments in the OTG are, as a rule, better able to provide social services at the appropriate level, as well as contribute to local development than the old structures. The new local governments in the OTG are more transparent and open to consultation and public participation. For example, local OTG councils often hold consultations with civic councils (“huge councils”). The “participation budget” program allows residents to apply for the budget resources of the OTG in support of local development projects initiated by them.
Reforms facilitate the involvement of citizens in political decision-making processes and the implementation of various projects at the local level. Citizens can take an active part in discussions regarding the vector of development of OTG. During the initiation and implementation of various steps to reform the TGs, heated discussions often arise - mainly between political, administrative and economic stakeholders, on the one hand, and members of the public, on the other. Thanks to such disputes, citizens gain experience in formulating their interests and using their representation in OTG self-government bodies.
Sectoral decentralization
Parallel reforms in several other areas of government are under the name “sectoral decentralization,” including in education and the provision of administrative services. OTG, for example, is allowed to create educational districts, which consist of core schools, where the main financial resources are concentrated and where the best existing teaching and learning practices are introduced. Supporting schools have local branches. As of September 2019, the OTGs were responsible for managing 369 of the 838 core schools in the country and 588 of their 1,332 branches. OTG and “cities of regional significance” are currently responsible for managing 45.5% of all schools, while 54.5% of schools are still under the control of district state administrations and district councils.
OTGs can also take responsibility for the provision of public services at the Centers for the provision of administrative services and their units, which operate in remote areas. As of September 2019, 168 of the 796 Centers for the provision of administrative services in Ukraine were under the management of OTG. In such cases, administrative fees for registration of births, marriages, divorces, residence, etc. come to OTG budgets, and not to district budgets. With the help of the new mobile units of the Centers for the provision of administrative services, their service is approaching residents of the remote territories of the OTG. Innovations in administrative services often lead to inter-municipal cooperation in providing new types of services to residents of more than one OTG.



3. Progress with consolidation to date
As of September 2019, 4,389 or 40% of the old small local communities, covering 41% of the territory of Ukraine, were merged into OTG. Currently, almost one third of the population lives in OTG (29.1%). Another 42% live in "cities of regional significance", which basically already have stable local self-government and, until recently, did not participate in the association. The rest of the population still lives in communities that continue to suffer from weak local government and are mainly managed by district state administrations. The central government has not yet been able to delegate to these communities the powers, responsibilities and financing associated with decentralization.
There are several reasons why some communities have not yet joined the voluntary association process. First, many non-united communities, as before, are unable or unwilling to negotiate the creation of OTG in a format that meets the criteria established in the center for classifying them as “self-sufficient”. They do not seek to take on additional responsibilities for managing social infrastructure, despite the promise of potential financial benefits from the association. In addition, local communities that already have lucrative businesses on their territory and that collect taxes from them in their budgets are often less interested in joining with poorer communities. At the same time, sometimes small local communities are afraid to unite with larger ones, fearing that their interests will not be sufficiently represented in the OTG.
Secondly, some regional and district councils and state administrations are in no hurry to share resources and functions with OTG. Sometimes they exercise administrative influence or even pressure on communities in order to prevent or postpone the formation of OTG. For example, only at the beginning of 2019, after long delays, the Transcarpathian regional administration allowed the formation of OTG on its territory, and only in September 2019 the long-term plan of OTG in this area was approved.
Leadership andthe staff of some state administrations and councils also does not support the reform, as it fears losing their jobs as a result of community unification and the concomitant transfer of OTG facilities and functions that, for example, were previously managed by district executive committees. On the other hand, today a number of officials of those state bodies that are in the process of losing their powers or are even foreseen for liquidation, run for elections or are oriented to positions in the councils and executive committees of new OTGs. These cases give hope that many regional and district officials will cease to resist decentralization over time and find their place in the new structure of local governments.
Against this background, the ongoing retraining of personnel must be continued, especially for the re-hiring of personnel from today's regional state administrations, which will sooner or later be abolished. Officials from the “old” system should receive the opportunity and qualifications for further work not only in the OTG, but also in the updated territorial divisions of the executive branch in the regions or in new enlarged areas, which are expected to appear at the second stage of the decentralization reform ( see Section 5).
The third factor slowing down the process of uniting local communities is the lack of coordination between ministries and departments in the center. Their conflicting signals make it difficult for local communities to make preliminary calculations of the costs and benefits associated with the creation of OTG. The Ministry of Regional Development, renamed and reformatted in September 2019 as the Ministry of Development of Communities and Territories, is the leading institution for decentralization. However, it is not responsible for some sectoral reforms that are developed and implemented at the regional level by other relevant ministries, such as the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Health, etc.
The numerous reforms that have been simultaneously taking place in Ukraine since 2014 are not always well coordinated and sometimes even contradict each other. For example, health care reform, which aims to expand the rights of patients and doctors in the field, provides for a certain centralization of financing and control of medical institutions. In addition, as of mid-2019, the final design of new hospital districts across the country is unknown.
Despite these and other problems, the budgetary decentralization of Ukraine and the unification of local communities are already contributing significantly to the political unity of the country, as well as the development of local democracy. These positive changes, however, are still incomplete and incomplete. As of mid-2019, their completion was an urgent issue in the light of the preference for completing the unification of territorial communities before the next nationwide local elections, scheduled for October 2020.
4. Tools for supporting local development
In order to reduce regional imbalances, the government and parliament also changed the institutional and financial framework for using subsidies to support local development. In 2014, the Parliament approved the State Strategy for Regional Development for the Period until 2020 (GSRR-2020), and in 2015 it adopted the law “On the Basic Principles of State Regional Policy”. GSRR-2020 is aimed at ensuring the territorial integrity of the state through promoting sustainable economic development, increasing the competitiveness of communities and stimulating interregional cooperation. One of the key features of the GSRR-2020 is that it applies standards and methods of planning and budgeting, as in the EU.
In particular, the GSRR-2020 is aimed at improving the multi-level coordination of economic development. It establishes horizontal coordination mechanisms for government agencies involved in decision-making on public investment, and also provides for vertical coordination between central and local authorities and local governments involved in the development and support of regional and local development projects. Horizontal coordination is led by the Ministry of Regional Development (since September 2019 - the Ministry of Development of Communities and Territories), which is responsible for including other executive bodies in the reform. Vertical coordination involves ensuring that each regional development strategy is formulated in accordance with the priorities set out in GSRD-2020, and that each local infrastructure development plan is consistent with the strategic objectives of the respective area. In each region, the Ministry of Regional Development (from September 2019 - the Ministry of Development of Communities and Territories), in collaboration with international donors, created Local Government Development Centers. These new entities help municipalities develop development plans within the institutional framework of the GSR-2020.
In addition to financing - in the form of subsidies paid until 2020 inclusively - of the institutional and social infrastructure of the OTG, the central government changed the role of the previously created State Fund for Regional Development (FIU). In order to support medium-term regional development projects agreed with the GSRD-2020, as well as to minimize nepotism and corruption in the selection of projects, the state budget should annually allocate at least 1% of its revenues to the FIU, while the FIU co-finances projects on a competitive basis. The mechanism for spending money by the FIU is more transparent than before 2014. Each year, the FIU distributes funding, calculated according to the approved formula, between different regions to support their projects.
The rules of the FIU require that the relevant projects be consistent with the development strategy of the respective region, and with the objectives of the GSRR-2020. Not only regions, but also OTG have the right to apply to the FIU for financing: they are allowed to develop projects on their own. Since February 2018, OTGs also have the right to receive communal property previously owned by the state on their territory in communal ownership. As of September 2019, 646 OTGs have already received 1,450.8 hectares of agricultural land for communal ownership.
However, the disadvantage of financial support for regional and local development is that it is often used to solve pressing problems, and not to increase the ability of OTG to generate stable tax revenues. In addition, the distribution of FIU funds on the ground is still not completely transparent, competitive or rational. In 2019, the Ministry of Regional Development indicated that some regional authorities received funding for projects that did not comply with their regional development strategies. In addition, 63% of the projects supported by the FIU are dedicated to single OTGs, while inter-municipal or inter-regional cooperation projects are still few. This prevents the pooling of resources of different OTG and does not allow local governments to fully use their new powers.
At the beginning of 2019, the Ministry of Regional Development announced that it intends to improve the regulatory framework of regional development by developing a new state strategy for regional development until 2027 (GSRR-2027). Its goals remain spatial development, competitiveness and effective management of regional development. The ministry expects that by the end of 2019 all regions will approve their regional development strategies for 2021-27, and most regions will develop action plans for their implementation. One of the key differences between the mentioned documents and the documents of the previous planning period will be the opportunity to receive financial support for the implementation of projects only if they comply with regional development strategies, which, in turn, will fit into the framework of the GSRR-2027.
In addition, this time the regions really got the opportunity to formulate their development strategies without a guide from the center, but taking into account the three main goals of the GSRR-2027. The question is how well they will cope with such a task. At stake are the chances of resolving the yet insurmountable task of the growing imbalances in regional development in Ukraine. The gradual reduction of interregional imbalances continues to be one of the most pressing tasks in Ukraine today. It is expected that a more effective coordination of the priorities of regional development strategies and the state strategy of regional development, both at the stage of their approval and at the implementation stage, can become an effective incentive to solve this problem.



5. Next steps and challenges for the future
In early 2019, the central government in Kiev announced the start of the second stage of decentralization. The new action plan aims to complete the reform program in 2019-21. However, the start of practical implementation of the second stage of the reform was complicated by the political calendar of 2019, during which three rounds of nationwide voting in the presidential and parliamentary elections were held, as well as the subsequent rotation of personnel in the legislative, executive and judicial branches of government.
One of the main tasks of the new stage is to increase the pace of the formation and expansion of OTG, so that - in the ideal case, fully - complete this process before the next nationwide local elections in the fall of 2020. The key to achieving this goal is the accelerated approval of such “long-term plans” for OTG in areas that will not only increase the speed of formation of OTG, but also establish effective local self-government throughout the country. On September 25, 2019, the new government approved a draft amendment to the relevant law, which will allow the Cabinet of Ministers to approve “long-term plans” without obligationfull participation of regional councils. So far, only 87.6% of the territory of Ukraine is covered by long-term plans for the formation of OTG in the regions. Now it’s the turn of the new convocation of the parliament - to consider this draft law or put it aside.
However, even if the adoption of this law is quick, it will probably be difficult to unite the remaining ununified communities, the number of which corresponds to about two-thirds of their original number, for the remaining local elections scheduled for October 2020. By the middle of 2020, approximately 6 572 small communities existing to this day will have to take one or another part in the formation of the GHG. To date, 951 OTGs have been created from the planned 1,200 (according to the above-mentioned Concept of local government reform and territorial organization of the government of Ukraine in 2014) or from 1,600-1800 (according to the aforementioned announcement of the then Prime Minister Volodymyr Groysman at the end of 2018).
This means that from 250 to 850 new OTGs must be created within one year. Such a goal seems overly ambitious. It is more likely that neighboring small communities will join existing OTGs. Moreover, as already outlined, the acceleration of the process of creating OTG will have to be carried out in many cases, not voluntarily, but administratively. Given the large number of communities that are yet to be united, tangible resistance to this process on the ground cannot be ruled out. Moreover, there is a danger of "substitution of goals." The rapid achievement of the required amount of OTG can be a priority task, which will replace the goal of creating OTG, the local authorities of which are able to provide residents with high-quality public services and effectively stimulate local development.
At the beginning of 2019, the Ukrainian government hinted that it could conduct a comprehensive assessment of the performance of the OTG in order to adjust their final format. It can be assumed that such an assessment will include a check on the financial sustainability of the GTP (including the share of local taxes in the GTS budgets), as well as a check on their success in relation to local economic development and the provision of public services. The results of such verification should be used to clarify the criteria for the formation of successful OTG in the future, and not only to confirm the "flaws" in the process of forming OTG on a voluntary basis.
The second stage of decentralization also includes a fundamental change in the administrative-territorial division of Ukraine at the district level. The formation of OTG shifted a significant degree of responsibility from the old district to the new municipal level. According to the current Constitution of Ukraine, district councils, elected in direct elections, are responsible for representing the common interests of residents of the settlements of the district. However, unification at the local level often leads to the creation of relatively large and powerful OTGs that do not need administrative support from today's district councils and district state administrations. Thus, most districts have already transferred the extensive responsibilities and financial resources of the OTG.
Since February 2018, a draft law has been registered in the parliament that offers a legal basis for the reform of districts according to the criteria that apply in the EU. This bill provides for the transformation of the existing 490 districts into 100 new enlarged areas, each with a population of about 150,000. However, the functions of these new district administrations and councils on an expanded territorial basis have not yet been finalized. Obviously, the planned radical reduction in the number of districts must be carried out simultaneously with the change of powers of larger government bodies and local authorities.
The enlargement of the districts will be from the very beginning administrative rather than voluntary. At the same time, during 2019, discussions in Kiev and regions continue both regarding the estimated number of united districts, and regarding the powers of the new district authorities. The inclusive format of the current discussion corresponds to the simultaneity of two interconnected processes of restarting the structure of the Ukrainian state - completion of the formation of OTG and preparation of the merger of the districts. Both processes will have a key impact on the provision of public services in the field. Thus, taking into account the opinions and needs of both ordinary Ukrainians and local and central elites regarding the total consequences of these changes is necessary.
A pressing and acute topic also remains constitutional reform in terms of decentralization. In particular, this refers to the introduction of a new institution of prefects, which should replace the heads of regional and district state administrations, as well as the right of regional and district councils to form their own executive committees. As you know, in August 2015, the draft of the corresponding - then failed - constitutional amendments was “tied” to an unsuccessful attempt to implement a specific requirement related to the Minsk Agreements 2014-2015. Now the newly elected parliament has to solve this fundamental task within the framework of decentralization - to bring the Constitution of Ukraine in line with the new realities of the country's political life.
In this regard, one of the most difficult challenges of the new stage of decentralization will be the question of what modality will be used for state supervision of the constitutionality and legality of decisions of new local governments in Ukraine. In the course of the decentralization reform, they receive expanded powers that can be used not only for the good of the country, but also for other purposes. For example, the sociological polls that we have already cited above demonstrate the request of citizens to hold local authorities accountable, which infringe on the rights of residents. The parliament of the previous convocation did not cope with the task of creating such a legal framework that would ensure both effective local self-government and the interests of the center. The solution of the question by which instruments it is necessary to carry out legal supervision of decisions of local self-government should take priority on the agenda of the new government.



6. Conclusions: the importance of decentralization for Ukraine and beyond
Despite various conflicts and imperfections in the early years of the reform, decentralization since 2015 has significantly improved the governance system in Ukraine. Rural and urban resources of the Ukrainian province are combined within the framework of more sustainable united territorial communities. The parallel implementation of sectoral reforms has improved the quality of public services provided at the level of new OTG. Decentralization also contributed to the development of local democracy.
However, the speed and scale of the formation of OTG were insufficient to fulfill the initial plans of the reformers. The new stage of decentralization, announced in January 2019, sets additional goals for a radical reduction in the number of districts and the introduction of executive committees of district and regional councils. Reforming the administrative-territorial structure of Ukraine is vital to ensure good governance and cohesion of the state, especially when its territorial integrity continues to be challenged from abroad. This ambitious agenda will not be easy to implement, especially if it needs to be completed before the local elections in October 2020.
Some of the problems that arose during previous attempts at decentralization can be traced after the Euromaidan revolution. The results of the reforms are still determined by the priorities of politicians in the center, although grassroots initiatives have also begun to play an important role. As before, the progress of reform is primarily hindered by resistance to change by entrenched regional elites and clans. However, the key difference between previous attempts to carry out territorial restructuring and the current decentralization process is that the central government pays special attention to improving the quality and accessibility of public services, and not just changing political relations between the center and the periphery.
The debate about decentralization in the early years of post-communist Ukraine was based on the understanding of “Europeanization” that prevailed after World War II. Elites, after Euromaidan, on the contrary, are better informed about modern standards of governance in the EU, including regarding the deconcentration of political power. However, politicians in Ukraine have so far been cautious about granting oblast and district councils the constitutional right to create executive committees. Politicians have readily accepted the idea of subsidiarity as a fundamental principle of multi-level governance. However, they do not dare to strengthen the regional level until the territorial integrity of the state is called into question by Russia.
While international technical and financial assistance is important, the success or failure of reforms such as decentralization continue to be driven primarily by internal factors. After the Euromaidan revolution of 2013-14, foreign donors consolidated their efforts in support of reforms in Ukraine, and this increased their influence and ability to promote decentralization. Well-coordinated consultations, technical assistance and financial support from abroad helped to prevent the government and parliament of Ukraine from ignoring the decentralization agenda.
In addition, the decentralization of Ukraine has at least four geopolitical dimensions. First, by making the state more efficient, responsive and sustainable, decentralization supports the role of the Ukrainian political system as a post-Soviet democratic counter-model with respect to the authoritarian "Eurasian" path promoted by Russia with its pseudo-federalism. Since decentralization helps Ukrainestate building and national self-determination, it indirectly contributes to the popularization of the general non-centralized model of post-communist governance, which implies an open society, political pluralism, strong civil society, and integration into Western structures for the former Soviet republics.
Secondly, the clearly non-federal and subregional philosophy of Ukraine’s decentralization reforms gives the main powers to local rather than regional self-government, thereby offering an antidote to Russian-fueled autonomy and separatism. By transferring power to the municipal level, decentralization complicates the Russian “hybrid war” against Ukraine and the Kremlin’s attempts to separate or annex one region or another. The less power regional or macro-regional capitals and clans have and the lower the level of political decision-making, the more difficult it becomes to prepare a particular region for capture by Russian irregular troops, secret agents and local collaborators. The growing stability of the Ukrainian state as a result of various reforms, including decentralization, is important not only for stability in Eastern Europe, but also has geopolitical significance.
Thirdly, decentralization is an expression of Europeanism and a way of further Europeanization of Ukraine. Being predominantly internally rooted and driven by reform, it is a demonstration of the European character of the Ukrainian nation. Moreover, this political transformation, like other liberalizing and democratizing reforms of Ukraine, makes the country more similar to other European states, where power has already become less concentrated. The more Ukraine is decentralized, the more it becomes “compatible” with the countries and principles of today's European civilization and suitable for full political integration into the European Union.
Fourth, non-federal and “sub-provincial” Ukrainian decentralization can become a model for countries that, like Ukraine, are threatened by (a) regional or macro-regional secessionism and / or (b) predatory neighboring states seeking to use internal divisions in that country for their own territorial expansion. Decentralization is currently helping Ukraine to increase the unity and cohesion of its state, despite the unstable situation in the territories of Donbass not controlled by the government.
In the future, this method of preventing separatism may well be applied to other countries. Highly centralized authoritarian post-Soviet states, not least Russia, one day may also want to transfer a large share of political power to the local rather than the regional level in order to protect themselves from possible collapse - whether fueled by internal or external forces. Thus, they could decide to follow the example of Ukrainian municipal decentralization rather than different federalist models. An example of the deconcentration of power in Ukraine may one day become a model for other, still authoritarian and centralized, post-Soviet countries - or even for completely different states in other parts of the world.
For these four and some other reasons, the decentralization reform of Ukraine launched in 2014 is a significant political transformation in the post-communist world. Against this background, Western countries should continue to support this process as generously and intensively as they currently do. Foreign journalists, and last but not least reporters from post-Soviet countries, should investigate more deeply its premises, course, successes, failures and consequences. Both international Ukrainian studies and researchers in the field of comparative studies of local governance in different parts of the world may find it useful to pay more attention to recent Ukrainian experience in the field of decentralization.
